title: Text mining for semantically enabled social browsing
segmentation: OK hello everyone, my name is you refresh.
I also come from the Ocean Institute.
This is the first time actually participating in Pascal.
So many of you don't know me.

I actually managed to get this grant for making Pascal pump priming project, which is called text mining for semantically enabled social browsing, and the main result is this semantic pointer application, which I will try to demonstrate and explain in this talk.
So what I'll talk about, just try to describe what I wanted to achieve.
And I'll tell you who are we targeting targeting with this demo?

Show the demo and then I'll stop it and describe the technology that is actually being showcased with this application and then also and then I'll describe how we actually plan to proceed with this, right?
So what are what is the goal?
We would like to sell the text mining technology that is developed inside Pascal project to this social browsing industry which I will describe in the next moment, right?
Right, it's a small part of Pascal.
And the main result that the medium with which we will do is is this semantic pointer application.
So what is social browsing, right?
This is the major question right now.
Who are we trying to sell this to, right?
Social browsing this industries are is consists of a couple of companies that are trying to implement this idea that one should not be alone while browsing the World Wide Web.
For instance, when we are visiting Google page.
We are there alone, but Google knows that there are millions of users actually viewing the same page at the very same moment in time, not millions but hundreds, thousands perhaps I don't know.
Right, and this is an old idea, so there are many solutions which already attempted this, and there are some companies who actually provide this kind of service right so?
There are companies like Pico Goblin yet who are actually focused on providing.
Interaction between users that are visiting the same page at the same moment.
Right, and this is something that has evolved with work with Web 2.0 very, very well.
There is one problem.
And this is that the Internet is so big that you can only meet someone at Google.
But since but once you browse their own page, you will never meet anyone because no one will be there at the same point in time, right?

So another company called Medium has just started like one year ago and recently they got $50,000,000 of funding and they're doing pattern analysis on click graph between web pages to actually define a broader collaboration context context.
So they're trying to connect people who are not just visiting the same page at the same moment in time, but also pages which are connected somehow, right?
They use graph analysis to say these two pages are similar.
They are close together, so you should collaborate.
You should see a person who is visiting that page as well, right?
And what we want to do with this small pump priming project is actually show how text mining can be used in this context, right?
And then try to impress the industry with it.
So here's another example of what is available today.
